awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Next-generation health monitoring systems with flexible electronics, novel algorithms and secure communication.
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site, Next-generation health monitoring systems with flexible electronics, novel algorithms and secure communication, at the University of Washington Bothell (UWB) will engage a diverse group of undergraduate students in interdisciplinary and collaborative research supervised by faculty members who have different but complementary specializations in biomedical engineering, signal processing and data security. One of the main objectives of this REU site is to increase the participation of women, underrepresented minorities, and first-generation students in undergraduate research in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. The overarching theme of these research projects is advancing the technologies for the development of reliable, low-cost and comfortable health monitoring devices having features such as delivering real-time data over the internet for distanced care and cloud processing. Recent advances in multidisciplinary research have brought together innovations in technologies, resulting in great strides in healthcare device development that has enhanced care efficiency, quality and efficacy in hospital services. The research projects will provide opportunities for the students to develop their research skills by exposing them to interdisciplinary, collaborative, cutting-edge, and accessible research. Each group of students will work on a specific project while collaborating with the other groups to solve a bigger problem.

The REU Site program will engage 10 participants per year for a rewarding 10-week summer research experience with dedicated and enthusiastic faculty members who have designed interdisciplinary and collaborative research projects. The primary objective of the REU Site program's projects is to develop reliable and comfortable health monitoring devices with real-time communication capability for remote data access to allow distance-care of patients. The development of these devices requires collaborative research work in the areas of medical devices, signal processing and data security. It is expected that a group of two students will work on each project. The projects are accessible to undergraduate students and, at the same time, are contemporary research problems with potentially novel solutions that can lead to publications. In addition, the program will emphasize the training of students in the fundamentals of conducting research. In line with this goal, weekly professional development seminars will be conducted on subjects such as abstract writing, research ethics and presentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The "Next-generation Health Monitoring Systems with Flexible Electronics, Novel Algorithms and Secure Communication" REU site had the following specific goals:

Goal 1: To increase the number of women and underrepresented students participating in undergraduate research training.

Goal 2: To disseminate research results through presentations or publications.

Goal 3: To increase the communication skills of the participants.

Goal 4: To increase the number of women and underrepresented students who pursue graduate studies.

Our evaluations show that the target of each of the goals has been successfully met. The REU site recruited 10 REU students per year for three years and engaged them in rewarding interdisciplinary research experiences. Of the 30 students who participated in the program, 21 (70%) were underrepresented students, and 16 (about 53%) were women. Most of the participants were from primarily undergraduate or minority-serving institutions.

The research projects provided opportunities for the students to work on collaborative and accessible research in the areas of medical devices, biomedical signal processing, and data security. The primary aim of the projects was to help the students develop research skills by exposing them to research methodologies, data collection and analysis, and disseminating research outputs. Mentoring was provided daily, so the students became independent in their research work. The students' contributions were reported at the 2018, 2019, and 2021 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) annual meetings. In each of the three years, the students gave five poster presentations, and a total of 16 students attended the conferences.  

From the outset of the 10-week program, the students were encouraged to develop their communication skills by having them write regular progress reports and make daily updates and weekly short presentations to their research group. At the end of the ten weeks, each student gave an oral presentation and wrote a report describing their progress. Furthermore, the students presented their work in a poster format each of the three years at the annual University of Washington Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium.

Students of the REU program participated in other weekly professional development training presented as part of the 'FUNdamental Summer Series' offered by the University of Washington Bothell's Office of Research. These professional development training topics include Courageous Conversations, Mental Health and Self-Care, Research Abstract Writing, Research Poster Design, Understanding Grad School, NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program,  Resume Writing, and Research Ethics. In addition, a 4-day 'Introduction to MATLAB Programming' training was provided to interested students.

Of the 24 students who completed their undergraduate degrees and whom we can track, 22 are working as engineers, several of whom are in the design and development departments. Also, 6 students (25%) have pursued or are pursuing graduate studies. Our surveys show increased interest among students in continuing research and pursuing an advanced degree(s) due to the REU experience. Many students expressed interest in pursuing graduate studies after gaining some industrial experience.
